paper_metadata.title: Nerve ultrasound in hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis: red flags and possible progression biomarkers
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for the TTR gene, including penetrance data for affected and unaffected carriers.

patients.phenotype: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTRv), with manifestations including carpal tunnel syndrome and polyneuropathy

individual_records.evidence_sentence: According to the neurophysiologic findings, 34 (55%) ATTRv subjects (mean age 64.4, range 36–86, mean BMI 24.2, range 14–38) were diagnosed with axonal polyneuropathy.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Pre-symptomatic carrier with no symptoms or signs of systemic amyloidosis
individual_records.evidence_sentence: 28 subjects (45%) did not show symptoms or signs of systemic amyloidosis including polyneuropathy.

functional_data.summary: Nerve ultrasound evaluation showed differences in cross-sectional area between affected and unaffected carriers.

variants.segregation_data: Segregation with disease in families is implied but not explicitly stated.
variants.additional_notes: The most frequent mutations were Phe64Leu, Val30Met, and Glu89Gln.
key_quotes: The most frequent mutations were Phe64Leu (22 subjects), Val30Met (13 subjects), Glu89Gln (11 subjects).
Prevalence of ATTRv polyneuropathy across the different mutations is reported in Table 2.

tables_processed.table_caption: TTR gene mutations in our ATTRv populations
Prevalence and severity of ATTRv polyneuropathy (PN) in the different genotypes

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text and tables.
